p: The strong antagonism of T. citrinoviride to A. solidipes seemed to be induced by diffusible compounds that inhibited the growth of A. solidipes and the formation of rhizomorphs. It was also proved that these compounds were metabolites and not enzymes since they could still suppress the growth of A. solidipes after denaturing any enzymes in the filtrates of Trichoderma isolates during autoclaving [ 276]. A further study indicated that compounds from the fermentation of T. longibrachiatum and T. harzianum in different media exhibited antibacterial and antifungal activities [ 277]. 6- n-pentyl-Î±-pyrone (6-PP) was the most active metabolite, at a concentration of 200 ppm completely suppressing the growth of A. mellea. Sorbicillin showed moderate antifungal activity on the fungi Paecilomyces variotii and Penicillium notatum but no activity against A. mellea [ 277].
